Summer School.

After the meeting of the Board
()f Trustees, on Tuesday afternoon,
President Remsen announced that
the second session of the summer
school of .the Johns Hopkins University will be held next July and
August. It will be open on July 2.
and continue six weeks.
The staff of instructors will include Prof. Edward F. Buchner,
director of the summer school ;
Prof. Lorrain S. Hulburt, mathematics; associate Prof. J. Ellicott
Gilpin, chemistry; associate Prof.
John A. Anderson, physics ; Dr.
Ronald T. Abercrombie, school hygiene; Prof. Clifton F. Hodge, of
Clark University, biology; Prof.
Arthur 0. Norton, of Harvard University, and Miss Lida Lee Tall,
supervisor of grammar grades in
Baltimore county, education; Prof.
De La Warr B. Easter, of Washington and Lee University, French;
Prof. Bert J. Vos, of the University
of Indiana, German; Prof. St.
George L. Sioussat, of Vanderbilt
University, history; Dean Charles
H. Barnwell, of the University of
Alabama, English literature; assistant Prof. Robert M. Gay,of Goucher College, and Mr. Samuel North,
head of the department of English
in the Baltimore Polytechnic Institute, English composition; Director
Agnes E. Harris, of the Florida
State College for Women, domestic
science; • Supervisor George M.
Gaither, of the Baltimore public
schools, manual training, and Mr.
T. deC. Ruth, Johns Hopkins University, Latin.

A Student Organization.

The move inaugurated by Mr.
Holmes at the recent meeting of
the students, to organize some sort
of permanent student council to look
after matters of general interest that
are not strictly concerns of the
Athletic Board, deserves commendation. We hope the committee
that is working on the question of
Such an organization will find it
feasible to report at an early occasion some definite method of securing the undoubted advantages the
plan offers.
These advantages are of two
kinds. First, there is a distinct
value in having a. recognized student organization that can act upon
important administrative matters.
The presiding officer is in a position
to call meetings for ascertaining the
feelings of the undergraduates about
various questions that arise, and to
act, either in person or through an
,executive committee, as the authorized head of the student body. If
a regular student council is provided for, it can be of service in negotiating with the Dean and the faculty committees in regard to matters
which have been too often settled
without hearing in an adequate way
what the students have to say about
thenl: The schedule, hazing regulations, banquet rows, and examination rules might all well enough be
determined with an eye to the
wishes of the student council.
The other class of advantages is
to be gained from the closer relations the new organization would
bring about between the students
themselves. Mass meetings might
readily be held at regular intervals,
even if there were little excuse besides, for the purpose of keeping
up college spirit and rousing interest
among the boys. At Virginia, we
understand, this is a regular part
of student life. It produces fellowship .and sympathy, and develops
often where least expected the qualities of leadership and inspiration
among the fellows who are called

Baseball Under Way.

Two long practices this past week
have brought out most of the baseball men in the University for the
preliminary work. On Wednesday,
Coach Harlan called the candidates
out in the cage for a two-hour
practice, during which the men had
a good deal of fielding and some
batting. They were instructed to
be careful and not to strain .their
throwing arms in the cold atmosphere of the cage. Dr. Roulston
helped Coach Harlan by batting out
grounders to the men. Practice
Saturday began at 1.15 P. M. and
lasted almost three hours. More
candidates were out, especially
from the medical school, including
six of last year's 'varsity nine. The
men had overcome The stiffness resulting from Wednesday's practice,
and worked more smoothly and
with much more spirit.
The coach seems satisfied with
the first week's work of the team,
and should things continue in as
good order during the winter, the
team will be in good condition and
will have gotten down the rudiments of training by the time the
out door work begins.
Basket-ball seems to have many
active backers here. It is an everincreasing marvel how Hopkins
students support and take part ill
so many different kinds of athletic
sports. All seem to flourish, and
to deserve to flourish. We hope
the basket-ball fiends will make
their game gain the place it deserves on the athletic calendar.

The Cotillon.

The second dance of the Cotillon
Club was held in McCoy Hall on
Friday night, and was, indeed, most
successful. The hall, besides being
hung with the class flags, was
draped with long black and blue
streamers, the combined effect of
which was very attractive.
The attendance was larger than
usual, and a goodly number of
"stags" kept things interesting.
Owing to the fact that it was Friday night, the dance continued until. half past twelve, but even this
time seemed very early. It seems,
in fact, to be the universial consensus of opinion that the cotillons
should be allowed to last later than
the time at which now we are aln•ost thrown out of the building.
We hope that the Board will find
a way to persuade' the University
authorities that the next dance be
continued later.
We wish to thank the chaperones
for their kindness in attending the
dance.

Summer School.

After the meeting of the Board
()f Trustees, on Tuesday afternoon,
President Remsen announced that
the second session of the summer
school of .the Johns Hopkins University will be held next July and
August. It will be open on July 2.
and continue six weeks.
The staff of instructors will include Prof. Edward F. Buchner,
director of the summer school ;
Prof. Lorrain S. Hulburt, mathematics; associate Prof. J. Ellicott
Gilpin, chemistry; associate Prof.
John A. Anderson, physics ; Dr.
Ronald T. Abercrombie, school hygiene; Prof. Clifton F. Hodge, of
Clark University, biology; Prof.
Arthur 0. Norton, of Harvard University, and Miss Lida Lee Tall,
supervisor of grammar grades in
Baltimore county, education; Prof.
De La Warr B. Easter, of Washington and Lee University, French;
Prof. Bert J. Vos, of the University
of Indiana, German; Prof. St.
George L. Sioussat, of Vanderbilt
University, history; Dean Charles
H. Barnwell, of the University of
Alabama, English literature; assistant Prof. Robert M. Gay,of Goucher College, and Mr. Samuel North,
head of the department of English
in the Baltimore Polytechnic Institute, English composition; Director
Agnes E. Harris, of the Florida
State College for Women, domestic
science; • Supervisor George M.
Gaither, of the Baltimore public
schools, manual training, and Mr.
T. deC. Ruth, Johns Hopkins University, Latin.

BALTIMORE, MD., FEB. 12, 1912
A Student Organization.

The move inaugurated by Mr.
Holmes at the recent meeting of
the students, to organize some sort
of permanent student council to look
after matters of general interest that
are not strictly concerns of the
Athletic Board, deserves commendation. We hope the committee
that is working on the question of
Such an organization will find it
feasible to report at an early occasion some definite method of securing the undoubted advantages the
plan offers.
These advantages are of two
kinds. First, there is a distinct
value in having a. recognized student organization that can act upon
important administrative matters.
The presiding officer is in a position
to call meetings for ascertaining the
feelings of the undergraduates about
various questions that arise, and to
act, either in person or through an
,executive committee, as the authorized head of the student body. If
a regular student council is provided for, it can be of service in negotiating with the Dean and the faculty committees in regard to matters
which have been too often settled
without hearing in an adequate way
what the students have to say about
thenl: The schedule, hazing regulations, banquet rows, and examination rules might all well enough be
determined with an eye to the
wishes of the student council.
The other class of advantages is
to be gained from the closer relations the new organization would
bring about between the students
themselves. Mass meetings might
readily be held at regular intervals,
even if there were little excuse besides, for the purpose of keeping
up college spirit and rousing interest
among the boys. At Virginia, we
understand, this is a regular part
of student life. It produces fellowship .and sympathy, and develops
often where least expected the qualities of leadership and inspiration
among the fellows who are called

Baseball Under Way.

Two long practices this past week
have brought out most of the baseball men in the University for the
preliminary work. On Wednesday,
Coach Harlan called the candidates
out in the cage for a two-hour
practice, during which the men had
a good deal of fielding and some
batting. They were instructed to
be careful and not to strain .their
throwing arms in the cold atmosphere of the cage. Dr. Roulston
helped Coach Harlan by batting out
grounders to the men. Practice
Saturday began at 1.15 P. M. and
lasted almost three hours. More
candidates were out, especially
from the medical school, including
six of last year's 'varsity nine. The
men had overcome The stiffness resulting from Wednesday's practice,
and worked more smoothly and
with much more spirit.
The coach seems satisfied with
the first week's work of the team,
and should things continue in as
good order during the winter, the
team will be in good condition and
will have gotten down the rudiments of training by the time the
out door work begins.
Basket-ball seems to have many
active backers here. It is an everincreasing marvel how Hopkins
students support and take part ill
so many different kinds of athletic
sports. All seem to flourish, and
to deserve to flourish. We hope
the basket-ball fiends will make
their game gain the place it deserves on the athletic calendar.

The Cotillon.

The second dance of the Cotillon
Club was held in McCoy Hall on
Friday night, and was, indeed, most
successful. The hall, besides being
hung with the class flags, was
draped with long black and blue
streamers, the combined effect of
which was very attractive.
The attendance was larger than
usual, and a goodly number of
"stags" kept things interesting.
Owing to the fact that it was Friday night, the dance continued until. half past twelve, but even this
time seemed very early. It seems,
in fact, to be the universial consensus of opinion that the cotillons
should be allowed to last later than
the time at which now we are aln•ost thrown out of the building.
We hope that the Board will find
a way to persuade' the University
authorities that the next dance be
continued later.
We wish to thank the chaperones
for their kindness in attending the
dance.
